Different textures and colors in igneous rocks are the result of variations in the cooling rate, composition, and crystallization of the rock. 

For example, in igneous rocks that cool slowly, large, well-formed crystals have time to grow, resulting in a coarse-grained texture. This is characteristic of many intrusive igneous rocks like granite. On the other hand, igneous rocks that cool rapidly, such as lava flows, did not allow time for minerals to grow, which produces fine-grained textures.

The mineral composition of the rock also plays a significant role in determining its color. For instance, light-colored igneous rocks, such as granite and rhyolite, are rich in light-colored minerals like quartz and feldspar, whereas dark-colored igneous rocks like basalt contain minerals like pyroxene and olivine. 

Another factor influencing the texture and color of igneous rocks is the presence of elements such as iron and magnesium, which can produce colors ranging from reds and oranges to greens and blues. Water, gas, and other volatile elements can also influence the texture and color of an igneous rock.
